column4: just had an interesting thing show up.  I partitioned an external usb2 300 gig drive using gparted, but sfdisk says that the partition is the wrong size and should be recreated
I don't know what I can tell u. Parted, sfdisk, and fdisk like to disagree a lot
that's funny.  so, which is the "most stable" of programs?
you don't happen to know how to tell sfdisk to use "all of the disk", do you?  the --help doesn't show anything like it
I have too many disks to sit down and figure out their sizes...
I don't think sfdisk has such feature. It seems to REQUIRES start/end params
that's even funnier... I have no idea what the specs are supposed to be for all of the drives.  I've blown away my windows server and am starting fresh in ubuntu
I know it kinda sucks. But I think your best shot is first figure out if the sfidk warning is anything to worry about and if parted did the right job
put yourself in my shoes... I have 14 hard drives (7 internal, 7 external usb2) ranging in size from 80 gig to 300 gig
and I want to partition each as a separate drive...  (just how I do things for safety sakes)
I think I'm going with gparted... even though I bitched that it's slow, it does at least allow me "ease of use"
and it seems to work... just wish there were an easy way to auto add any new partitions to /etc/fstab
sorry if I can't be more helpful. Partitiong is something I've been struggling with
nah... you have been helpful.  you've shown to me that it's "not just me"
know of an easy way to add partitions to /etc/fstab (short of editing it myself?)
what I think I'm going to do is physically label all the exernal drives one-by-one and partition/name them in ubuntu with the label name
that way I can easily know which drive I need to take off in case of failure

everyone keeps telling me that...  in windows I set the drives up individually and used robocopy to duplicate data to like-sized drives.  it worked for me... never lost anything (even after 2 bad "re-install the os" crashes)
i use LVM, not raid though
oh that kind of mirroring
i don't know how u can possibly achieve that with losing half your hair because IP address, net conf, hardware conf, hostnames, etc., all gets copied
